questions.question: What is the chemical formula of the spin crossover material based on a cyanido-bridged FeII–MoIV assembly discussed in the paper?
questions.answer: FeII2[MoIV(CN)8](1-(3-pyridyl)ethanol)8⋅4H2O

questions.question: What phenomenon does the FeII2[MoIV(CN)8](1-(3-pyridyl)ethanol)8⋅4H2O compound exhibit between 200 and 50 K?
questions.answer: It exhibits incomplete spin crossover, with 21% of the high-spin FeII sites changing to low-spin FeII sites.

questions.question: What method was used to synthesize single crystals of FeMo?
questions.answer: The slow-diffusion method was used to synthesize single crystals of FeMo.

questions.question: What is the role of 1-(3-pyridyl)ethanol in the FeII2[MoIV(CN)8](1-(3-pyridyl)ethanol)8⋅4H2O compound?
questions.answer: 1-(3-pyridyl)ethanol acts as an organic ligand in the cyanido-bridged Fe–Mo assembly.

questions.question: How does the temperature affect the spin state of FeII sites in FeMo according to the study?
questions.answer: The temperature decrease from 300 K to 50 K leads to a gradual transition of FeII sites from high-spin to low-spin state.

questions.question: What causes the incomplete and gradual spin crossover in FeMo?
questions.answer: The incomplete and gradual spin crossover is attributed to the elastic frustration between the high-spin and low-spin FeII sites.

questions.question: True or False: Thermal hysteresis was observed in the spin crossover phenomenon of FeMo.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: True or False: The Fe–Mo coordination network in FeMo is two-dimensional.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What analytical technique confirmed the presence of terminal and bridging cyanides in FeMo?
questions.answer: IR spectroscopy confirmed the presence of terminal and bridging cyanides in FeMo.

questions.question: True or False: The crystal structure of FeMo remains unchanged across the temperatures 82 K, 120 K, and 200 K.
questions.answer: True

questions.question: What is the significance of the racemic organic ligand in the synthesis of FeMo?
questions.answer: The racemic organic ligand, 1-(3-pyridyl)ethanol, is significant for introducing variation in the organic ligands coordinating to the SCO sites, which is important for the design of SCO phenomena and functionalities.

questions.question: True or False: The FeMo compound exhibits nonlinear optical properties.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What potential future application is suggested for non-centrosymmetric cyanido-bridged SCO materials with chiral ligands?
questions.answer: Non-centrosymmetric cyanido-bridged SCO materials with chiral ligands are suggested to have potential for exhibiting second harmonic generation.

questions.question: True or False: The FeMo compound was synthesized using a high-temperature reaction method.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What is the role of L-ascorbic acid in the synthesis of FeMo?
questions.answer: L-ascorbic acid acts as a reducing agent in the synthesis of FeMo.

questions.question: True or False: The FeMo compound exhibits a complete spin crossover transition.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What is the crystal system and space group of FeMo?
questions.answer: FeMo crystallizes in the cubic system with the space group of Ia3d.

questions.question: True or False: The synthesis of FeMo involves the use of a racemic mixture of R- and S-1-(3-pyridyl)ethanol.
questions.answer: True

questions.question: What is the effect of temperature on the Fe–N bond lengths in FeMo?
questions.answer: The Fe–N bond lengths decrease as the temperature decreases from 200 K to 82 K, indicating a partial transition from high-spin to low-spin state.

questions.question: True or False: The FeMo compound was characterized using single-crystal x-ray diffraction at only one temperature.
questions.answer: False
